commentBody: Really enjoyed this one- it was on my wavelength. My only slowdown was the southwest, but it resolved pretty quickly on my second pass. Some clever and fun misdirects here.

So wished the famous British rock group would be Wang Chung, but it didn‚Äôt fit, and they‚Äôre not really that famous. Close, but‚Ä¶

- Tom
The "T-Rex" clue that had been proposed for 13D would surely have been Friday-worthy. Thanks at least sharing that.
For me, this was the easiest (still satisfying, though) Friday puzzle in ages. I must have been on the same wavelength as the constructor!

"Do you know how to clear an Etch-a-Sketch?"
"I'm kind of shaky on that."

("We'll have to have an art-to-art.")

Fun puzzle with some clever clues, including drawer with knobs for ETCHASKETCH, one of the favorite toys from my childhood.  The other that grabbed my attention was famous British rock group, which had me scratching my head and cursing myself for not being able to come up with something that I would expect to be in my wheelhouse. But then, suddenly,  I had sufficient crosses to see STONHENGE.  Score one for Jen Burch.

The timing feature is way off the last two days, adding 20 minutes to my time yesterday and 15 today.  No big deal to me (I‚Äôm not a speed solver), but, for those that care, be aware that you may be getting bad information.
Nice puzzle with a lot of pleasantly tricky stuff. And I'll bang a gong for that great T. Rex clue that the editors scrapped.
This was a fun one, although a little easier than many Fridays. OTOH, there were some sneaky misdirects and clever clues. Enjoyed!
A bit too easy for a Friday (maybe I was just on the constructor's wavelength today) but 10/10 for the fresh and witty cluing

I lucked out because 1A was a total gimme for me. Got it in about two seconds. If you‚Äôre not familiar with GRANDMA MOSES you should check her out. She was self taught and didn‚Äôt start painting until late in life. Her paintings of the Hudson Valley capture something that even the best trained artists can‚Äôt. Loved STONEHENGE as well.

Nice solid Friday puzzle. I've got to disagree that CURST is suboptimal ‚Äî a word that appears 24 times in Shakespeare's canon is certainly fine ‚Äî but, as Sam says, the clue is suboptimal (and that may be due to the editor). "Afflicted √† la Shakespeare" would have been spot-on.
Not my wavelength. So not so easy for me. But very satisfying. And some great clueing. Took me one cigar and two bourbons. So timing was perfect.

I loved everything about this puzzle, start to finish. For most of it I never knew what to expect. I started out with oil painter, only to find out a minute later that it had to be wrong.  Then filled in ADIOSAMIGO and took it out again, because I was determined to write in a (wrong!) cross or two, then, of course, put it back.

Assuming that the rock group was a band, I was trying to remember every British rock band I had ever heard of, and burst out laughing in delight when it turned out to be as clued, a group: STONEHENGE (maybe my favorite clue of the year).

Thank you, Jem Burch, for a puzzle that was a joy to work.  I sincerely hope that there will be MORETOCOME!
Southwest was rough. Not sure why. Just lots of little things not clicking. Otherwise tons of satisfying moments.

Self Taught for Folk Artist; Chess Board for Royal Court. Didn't take long to correct those but it made for some, er, puzzy-aches, such as "Glove That For You" and "ABS'ED" (someone fit in mind and body is abs'ed indeed, as well as being latted and pec'd). Even though the cluing for "F E M" is a little complicated, so much better than that clunker recently about some partners in female romantic relationships. Where was the Vetoer for that one? Vetoer. What a terrible but great word. It's not new to the NYTXWs but it's been a while. (Once, a few years after the Kill Bill movies came out, it was clued as "Bill Killer" which probably had more kick then than it does now). Abled, OTOH, is just a curst word. If a poet used that word in a coffee house, I'd stand up, stub out my Gitane, tilt my beret, and leave. Well, a good puzzle, gently Friday. TGIF indeed. Can't believe the eds took away that T-Rex clue and replaced it with the utterly humdrum Bowie-Ziggy one. Come on Fagliano, all that glitters is indeed gold! Tomorrow night I'll announce once again the Puzzle of the Year contest. I hope you'll put into Replies your favorites as nominees. For example, here's one of my faves, which I remembered because there was a puzzle of hers earlier this week: Sarah Sinclair & Paolo Pasco's 6/27/24 pizza shaped puzzle. The ingenuity of the 39-rebus-squares and its toppings is a tour-de-force. Check it out: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2024/06/27
A fun related fact: in the summer of 2023 my family had a week vacation in which we stayed at a house in upstate New York where GRANDMA MOSES had worked as a housekeeper when she was young.
As a lifelong Washingtonian who grew up on the Salish Sea, you might know what my favorite clue was today.

Last letter I entered was the F in TGIF, and that solved the puzzle! 
A great puzzle, and a great start to my F!

I am SURE that Jem came to this on her own,  but I have to point out that on 11/27/2020 Robyn Weintraub clued "Classic British rock group" for STONEHENGE. 
(Yes I'm obsessive/compulsive, but it's my all-time favorite clue)
Merry Christmas and Happy Holidays, everyone!

Self Taught for Folk Artist; Chess Board for Royal Court. Didn't take long to correct those but it made for some, er, puzz-aches, such as "Glove That For You" and "Absed" (someone fit in mind and body is abs'ed indeed, as well as being latted and pec'd). Even though the cluing for "Fem" is a little complicated, so much better than that clunker recently (Dec. 15: [Some partners in lesbian couples]). Where was the Vetoer for that one? Vetoer. What a horrible, no good, ugly, great word. It's not new to the NYTXWs but it's been a while. (Once, a few years after the Kill Bill movies came out, it was clued as "Bill Killer" which probably had more kick then than it does now). Abled, OTOH, is just a curst word. It's just a drag, man. Well, a good puzzle, gently Friday. TGIF indeed. Can't believe the eds took away that T-Rex clue and replaced it with the utterly humdrum Bowie-Ziggy one. Come on Fagliano, all that glitters is indeed gold! Tomorrow night I'm going to put in one of my announcements about the Puzzle of the Year contest, so I hope you will be thinking of nominees to put as Replies to it. Here's one of my picks, for example, which I remembered because there was a puzzle of hers this week: Sarah Sinclair & Paolo Pasco's 6/27/24 pizza shaped puzzle. The ingenuity of the 39-rebus-squares and its toppings is a tour-de-force. Check it out: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2024/06/27
Great puzzle!

That T. Rex clue is brilliant and like so many in the comments I wish I had gotten to solve it. 

I tried for way too long to make Stone Roses work as the famous British rock group. Didn't think they were that famous....

I enjoyed this puzzle a lot and finished well under my Friday average.  I had Oxford shoe before ETON COLLAR (that's a thing, right?). Like others, I also liked the STONEHENGE clue, which brings up images of an 8" replica as part of a Spinal Tap stage set. I also enjoyed seeing SALISH in the puzzle. Our minor league baseball team is the Indians, which I feel a little weird about but they work closely with the Spokane Tribe and their home jerseys and a lot of their fan merch is in Salish which is cool. We also have a Salish school which was unfortunately the target of a hate crime during the T45 years; hopefully we don't have a repeat of that. Finally, I'm not sure if I'm understanding the T-Rex clue? Is it because GLAM ROCKERs are all dinosaurs?
From FATS Domino to Just KEN, and Grandma Moses to ANN Patchett, what's not to love in this puzzle? OK, maybe RFS.  Very easy-going for a Friday. Thanks Jem.

At first I was only able to fill the NE quadrant on my own. Then I looked up some stuff I was clueless about (FOLK ARTIST, FATS, RFS, OHARE, ROTH, ANN Patchett, TED) and that allowed me to complete the puzzle. The clueing turned out to be just about on my wavelength - wittily misleading in an enjoyable way. Thank you Jem Burch for the mental workout.

HECTOR as 'be a pest to' was new to me. I checked the etymology online. Interesting. How common in actual English is this use of the word? I haven't learned it in 40 years so it doesn't seem to be common at all in literature, movies and games.
My stubborn insistence on letters of relief being TANF prevented me from making sense of the left side of the grid for way too long. Lots of good misdirection throughout.
This took me a tiny bit longer than my usual Friday. A few misdirections had to be worked out, then I got there. Nice clueing throughout!
The app is saying I took 1:10 to complete this, but it was half that. At one point the page went blank. Anybody else getting the same bug? iOS app‚Ä¶

I loved this puzzle! Very satisfying to struggle and then be rewarded with so many üí° moments. 

Since I‚Äôm going to a Bridgerton-themed ball for New Year‚Äôs Eve, I hope there will be a ROYALCOURT awaiting. Bridgerton is set well before the introduction of the ETONCOLLAR, so I have no idea what the handsome young RAKEs in attendance will wear.  I may be able to get my husband to wear a VEST over and existing white shirt. I‚Äôm lucky he‚Äôs putting up with this frivolity, tbh.  Since we‚Äôre doing Dry January, I won‚Äôt bring along a take-home FLASK üòâ .


Adeus AMIGOs!!!
Many great clues (and definitely loved T-Rex clue), but the one that made me laugh out loud was 37D "feathery layers." Hen and egg puns are the best.

Themeless puzzle? No way. This was 100% a ‚ÄúHome Alone‚Äù theme, and not just because of OHARE. You‚Äôve got a France reference, LIGHT TIMER, and ERGO (though that‚Äôs a subtle ‚ÄúHome Alone 2‚Äù entry). Maybe I‚Äôve just been watching it too much on TV this holiday season, but I hope the ties were intentional.
Fun puzzle!  Finished with no cheating too.  Kudos to the constructors!, thanks
I LOVED THIS FOR ME üòÅ

8D went in without a second thought because I saw it recently in another puzzle.  It tricked me that time because I had entered I LOVE THAT you try, which I think throws evens more shade.  I wasn't about to get fooled again.

I briefly had TanF for TGIF, but otherwise I just PURRed along to the finish.

Great Friday puzzle. The top half came easily, the bottom, not so much, making a lovely chewy Friday.
STONEHENGE made me laugh out loud; it‚Äôs just up the road from us so a frequent sight as we drive around. Never go near it on either Solstice though; impassable with all the Druids, Pagans and assorted tourists.
Wasn‚Äôt aware of 1A. In my ignorance I was thinking biscuits or some such line. Forgive me. The crosses helped it along so felt a bit sheepish when she revealed herself. 
Loved, loved the clues for 13D and 34 (plus the Marc Bolan bonus).

I‚Äôm surprised at how relatively easy and doable people found this puzzle.  Most of it, yes, i t zoomed night through.  BUT I found that tiny bottom left corner near impossible. It felt like every clue could have been a pun even though there was no sign of it.  Or it felt like the words there were much more exotic than the rest of the puzzle.  I thought those 8 words were going to be a streak killer and I got to the answer only by staring for a long time and some luck.
So wanted DECK and ROYAL FLUSH for 67A and 62A, respectively. Just not in the cards today.

Count me in with "Team T-Rex".  Fun with lots of "aha!" moments with the God of Thunder the last to fall (ABLEr >>>ABLED). 

We must have a good representation from the helping professions with at least 2 commenters leading with TanF for TGIF.  

Nicely done and thanks.

Strands Thread.  No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #299
‚ÄúBack in style‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

One of the themers just did not seem to fit with the others.
I‚Äôm with all those who were delighted with the Stonehenge clue, and in fact found lots to like in this Friday puzzle, including Jem's constructor notes.

I flew through the top half of this puzzle, but got completely stuck on the bottom half.

"Heckle" instead of HECTOR, "The Beatles" instead of STONEHENGE, "taxi" instead of MEGA... these mistakes threw me off. I had to Google the few googlable (is that a word?) clues to get me back on track.

[Feathery layers] was a great clue, it had me thinking boas? Down? There were a lot of good ones.

All in all, a fun Friday!

Friday crosswords are usually my least favorite, but I loved this one for me. Despite being held up by ‚Äúchessboard‚Äù for ROYAL COURT and ‚Äúheckle‚Äù for HECTOR for way too long, I found this to have just the right combination of trick and treat. 

ETCH A SKETCH  made me smile, as did STONEHENGE. (I haven‚Äôt been doing this long enough to be aware of the previous occurrences.) Too bad T Rex was snuffed out.
some tricky ones today! i really enjoyed 19A and 66A

Really nice puzzle. .Actually surprised to see that so many found this unusually easy. Not all that easy for me, of course, and had to cheat a bit, but still ended up being an enjoyable solve.

First puzzle find today was one that is very appropriate for me. A Tuesday from October 7, 2003 by Steve Jones. Three 15 letter theme answers. Here are the clues and answers for those: 

"Is like a stumped puzzle solver?"
DOESNTHAVEACLUE

"Like a stumped puzzle solver?" 
ATALOSSFORWORDS

"Where a stumped puzzle solver goes?"
BACKTOSQUAREONE

And... a couple of interesting puzzle finds today. I'll put those in replies. 

....

While I finished the puzzle without much difficulty or looking up anything, it definitely was not one of my favorites. Got hung up for a little while in the SE - couldn't figure out what kind of music that rock group played!! The crosses gave me the answer, although I didn't get it, duh, until I read an xword blog before Wordplay. I should have remembered that it had been used before, by Robyn and another constructor who apparently beat her to it. I also need to stop doing these puzzles before my night owl PST bedtime.

What made this a turn-off for me was the unknown "I LOVE THAT FOR YOU" and EMO -core. Answers like those are for solvers much younger than I. But I did appreciate ETCHASKETCH!
Thanks for slowly pulling me out of my holiday food coma....I love that for us! Stonhenge particularly jocular. Bravo!

This one hit my pleasure zone again and again:
‚Ä¢	Gorgeous single-word answers (LITHE, SAVORY, HECTOR).
‚Ä¢	ANN Patchett, whose books melt my heart.
‚Ä¢	Longs that roll off the tongue (GIVE OR TAKE, MORE TO COME, ADIOS AMIGO).
‚Ä¢	That terrific ETCH-A-SKETCH clue ‚Äì [Drawer with knobs?].
‚Ä¢	The number 18 right next to MILA.
‚Ä¢	BATHE and LATHE because ‚Äì and I don‚Äôt know why ‚Äì I love the feel of words that end in ‚Äúthe‚Äù (such as lithe, soothe, scythe, clothe, and breathe).

Filling this in was a bit like tubing down a river, repeatedly charmed by sights and sounds of nature.

This puzzle contains six NYT answer debuts.  Debut answers are not necessarily special, but, IMO, all today are very worthy additions to the oeuvre: ETON COLLAR, GLAM ROCKER, FOLK ARTIST, LIGHT TIMER, ROYAL COURT, I LOVE THAT FOR YOU.  And they add pop to the grid.

One of those sweet puzzles which, in addition to delighting my brain‚Äôs work ethic, allowed me to bathe in beauty throughout.  Thank you so much for this, Jem!

Alas, Sam, [Famous British rock group] won't make it onto @Lewis' clues-of-the-week list, as STONEHENGE, clued similarly, appeared as: [*English rock group] Tues.(!) Sept. 29, 2015 Kurt Krauss [Classic British rock group] Fri. Nov. 27, 2020 Robyn Weintraub :-) I wasn't doing NYT XW regularly in 2015, but I remember the 2020 appearance--It had me smiling all weekend! Now here's some truly Famous British* GLAM ROCKERS: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fOobUyAl_Vw *Actually, one was American, if memory serves.

With a name like Grandma Moses, in Old Testament times I think she could have been more like a thunder god.

A puzzle that started lightning-fast for me (top left), slowed in the bottom left, but still finished as a light timer over all.

OK well this is great. I‚Äôve been doing the NYT crossword for probably 40 years, but never in the app‚Ä¶ my daughter signed me up for Christmas, and I already love it so much it might become a problem! I especially like reading the comments after really good puzzle (like this one!)
Totally did not get the Stonehenge joke. I figured, okay some band I‚Äôve never heard of. Also means the pin on feathery layers because the N was my last entry. Good thing I read the comments.

This was a tough one for me, perhaps because my brain had been numbed by watching the worst football game ever. Yikes, Seattle and Chicago.

Was delighted to see SALISH. And I laughed out loud at the clue for STONEHENGE.

Terrific puzzle. Happy Boxing Day from our annual trek north of the border.
I completely agree - Stonehenge was a fantastic clue and I had to celebrate out loud when I finally cracked it !

I was unfamiliar with the verb "to HECTOR" (I was trying to make it HECkle)--turns out, per OED, it derives--through a couple steps--from the prince of the Trojan ROYAL COURT Hector; although I'm still not sure whether the one he was "bully; to brag, bluster, domineer"-ing was his foe, the Greek Achilles (notable for his HEELs); his brother, Paris (whose lover and her sister both emerged from EGGS); or perhaps the THUNDER GOD Zeus himself, who started the whole thing when he allowed Eris to throw such a hissy fit when she wasn't invited to the  Olympia High PROM.

Well...TGIF! About 1/3 average time. The cluing was very much on my wavelength. 
Had ETONJacket confidently on first pass, but that changed fast. 
Thought 24D would be "heckle",  and was really happy to change it to HeCTOR. Excellent word!
Bottom left was the last to go - deceptively simple, but even with the "eg" I was trying to think of another ride service besides Lyft. 
Hope there is MORETOCOME from Jem Burch.
Great, chewy, challenging puzzle. I also delighted at STONEHENGE. Also MEGA. Brilliant.

This felt way too easy for a Friday. However, I have felt incredibly annoyed when others remark the same on days I've struggled! So this one just happened to fit with my limited knowledge and I'll take it!

I suppose it's a mark of experience when you read "Famous British rock group" and immediately write STONEHENGE.

ETCHASKETCH and GLAMROCKER also came instantly. HENS for "Feathery layers" did not. Was surprised to read that "feathery" can directly substitute for "feathered", but so various dictionaries informed me. ERGO, calling an emu "feathery" is apparently OK.

As the remarks above indicate, I'm not finding much to say about today's puzzle. It seemed a perfectly solid Friday construction, though perhaps a bit on the gentle side to me.

Fun clueing! I especially love when puzzles introduce me to terms I‚Äôve never encountered. This introduced me to the Eton Collar, and a brief google search brought me to a photo of a young Winston Churchill wearing one.
Having chessboard instead of royal court certainly slowed me down!

I didn't know SALISH, and I've never seen "Home Alone" (I was an adult when it came out, and it just never occured to me to rent it for my kids). Still managed to guess the "H," though. 

I got this one cleanly, without lookups, not because it was a bit easier than a usual Friday, but because of my amazing skill and insight. And I'm not going to mention the embarassing amount of time that took.

I came here to complain about "curst," but since the constructor acknowledged that it was a sub-optimal clue, they stole my thunder, so to speak (I struggled with the Zeus clue despite being pretty good with Greek mythology).
i got it all in 25 minutes between spoonfulls of breakfast, but i still don't get hung for chilled.  what am i missing?

Thank you, Jem, for a very fine Friday puzzle and your notes. I loved this for me despite the fact that I kept falling asleep which did nothing good for my Friday average (an exhausting seasonal business issue not a boring puzzle issue).

I agree with Lewis regarding the many clever, fun clues and answers. I may have actually turned red with embarrassment when I got STONEHENGE and kept wondering why I had never heard of that famous rock group until‚Ä¶D‚Äôoh!
Loved this puzzle. Multiple missteps and re-thinks were great fun. No lookups, no checking comments or notes, just a delightful group of smart clues and answers.

The SW and SW central had me STUMPed for quite a while despite having FLASK,STATIC, and SHORT NOTICE in place.
Congrats to Jem Burch!  (Are you related to the Burch family who lived on Briarcliff Road in Atlanta?  Oh, the Puzzle.)  

35D clues a Palomino as being TAN.  
It so happens that PhysicsDaughter's horse Carter (the love of her life) is a Palomino, and in no wise is he TAN.  He is a lovely, soft gold, with a personality to match.  He is very calm and unflappable, which is perfect since PhysDau is, according to the clue for 53D, not ABLED.  (Both of us thought first of SOUND for that spot.)

  I'd say more, but the entry is ridiculous: would ANYbody use that awkward word? Discussion seems superfluous....but DISABLED, on the other hand, works.  
("Differently-ABLED, however, is ridiculous--a mawkish attempt to make up for acknowledging reality.)  Our daughter is 44, and she has been disABLED since that second heart surgery at age 7 months.  The fact that she has a PhD and is a researcher with the Corps of Engineers would suggest that both DISabilitty and Ability can co-exist (even comfortably, if inconveniently.)  
Okay, ....yes, I keep a soapbox in the closet; it's often needed.

Wouldn't Shakespeare have spelt it "CURS'D"?  Who had an original Folio?  Please check!
No News Quiz today?

Smoothish - had to abandon the NW, my usual starting point, and loop back around, but no real hang ups. Nice cluing - liked Uber alternative, after years of writing in Lyft or, less often, taxi - a misdirect for frequent solvers. But, really, I'm just posting to give you Ylvis's (of what does the fox say fame) Stonehenge - some explicit language https://youtu.be/mbyzgeee2mg?feature=shared

Because my brain sees patterns where none seem to exist, I note that in the past week we've had:
LITE BRITE
RUBIK'S CUBE
ETCH A SKETCH
Can Spirograph be next? Or Shrinky Dinks?

For future reference, Flea's real name is Michael Balzary. Face-palmed when I got FATS Domino.

I may point out that TGIF are [Letters of relief] only when, in fact, one has Saturday off. Actually, I might have thought that at 4 am this morning, as I have today off--but not tomorrow. My schedule changes from week to week, although in the last couple months I've been more likely to exclaim "TGIW!"

Once, many years ago, my Brother-in-Law asked my Partner, 'So when's Bill's weekend this week?"

"Jim, you know Bill doesn't get weekends!"

Me: "No, actually Jim, it's Tuesday and Wednesday--thank you for asking!"

He gets it--so many people don't. The tunnel vision of the nine-to-five.

Alas, I had to remove my comfortable OXFORDSHOE and replace it with a stiff ETONCOLLAR. This was a very enjoyable Friday puzzle with no lookups or naticks.

TIL: Fats Domino‚Äôs real name, Salish, and Mojo Dojo Casa House. (I saw Oppenheimer instead.)

‚ÄúFamous British rock group‚Äú is my favorite clue of 2024!
This was a fun Friday. My first answer for 27A Lab Container was FENCE though.

Very nice Friday and the clue for Stonehenge brought back a very nice memory of an old school friend who sang in a rock group called "The Stone Ponies" and was captain of the football team about 100 years ago.
'Many a T-Rex contemporary?' is really a wonderful clue!
Nice Saturday challenge.  I finished it in record time, GIVE OR TAKE thirty minutes üôÇ!

Took 18% longer than average.  Like others, I loved the clues for STONEHENGE and HENS.  Solid Friday, and wouldn't have blinked had it run on Saturday.  NE came quicker than the rest of the grid.  Good job, Jem Burch!

Delightful puzzle, fun cluing.

MORE TO COME ?, please, Jem.

Like @Gayle and others, I plunked in LYFT for  65A. Then was so proud of myself for switching to LEGS. I just could NOT get the SW today, even after the column gave me P--M so I replaced STYLE. Finally peeked at answer key and several DOH moments. Oh, THAT meaning for UBER! Running WATER!  Simplest meaning for "in" rather than "hip" or "with it"!
So many "aha" moments in this one. Great clueing
I loved this puzzle.

When I started this I thought I had no chance of finishing.   It seemed like it took me 10 minutes to find a couple of answers that I felt confident enough to write in.  From those I had a short spurt where I got a fourth to a third of the puzzle filled in, but them I hit a wall.   To that I closed my eyes and fell asleep.   To my surprise, when I awoke my brain started coming up with answers to the clues, and in the end I finished in 38 Minutes, which for me is about 15 minutes faster than my average Friday.    What a difference walking away can make.

An enjoyable puzzle that I found mostly easier than most Fridays, but not everywhere.  My big hangup is "chilled" = HUNG.  Why????  I suppose in the sense of lounging around and taking it easy?  But when you're "chilling" -- a verb I never use, btw, -- aren't you HANGing OUT?  Or HANGing LOOSE?  I definitely did not like this clue/answer.

Other than that, the puzzle was fine.  FEM led me right in at the outset and I never looked back.

I was fortunate enough to see that famous British rock group last spring. But I only grokked the clue with crosses. Today's puzzle was a challenge (understatement): took me a full 30 percent longer than my average. But enjoyable nonetheless. (I don't think my brain was fully engaged: took me forever to figure out OTOH, which is something I use with regularity.)
Good one!

I loved this puzzle. It was one of those that needed to simmer for a bit - I did around half of it, including the NW corner, last night, and then got stuck, so I put it down, and when I came back this morning everything just fell into place in my head so neatly. The clues were great because they were of that kind were at first they make no sense but then when you understand it's incredible.
Nice puzzle and very enjoyable. Didn't seem like a Friday level though.
Fun puzzle but way too easy for a Friday

I‚Äôm really not big on political correctness for its own sake, and I don‚Äôt love the nitpicking of words with valid acceptable usages that sometimes goes on here. That said, you could have done better with the curing on 53D: ‚ÄúPossessing a full range of physical and mental faculties.‚Äù  

It may seem like a subtle nit, but as far as I‚Äôm concerned it is careless to label a person as abled or disabled.  A person who has a specific disability is not ‚Äúdisabled‚Äù, and to say otherwise can be demeaning. Therefore, IMO, this clue could as well be seen as possibly demeaning to people who are not fully ‚Äúabled.‚Äù

Argue/disagree if you must.

Strands #299
‚ÄúBack in style‚Äù
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üü°üîµüîµ

Not in my world.

Avoid spoilers, plz, until after "view all replies"
Is ‚Äúemo‚Äù not already its own genre? Why the need to add -core?
Fun puzzle, just wanted to say I enjoyed the original clue for GLAMROCKER very much!
Nice easy Friday. Loved how this one unfolded. It was a challenge without being frustrating.
Had to look up the Boomer clue, "Grandma Moses" but that pretty much unlocked the NW quad of the puzzle.

As with almost anything "trendy", I've never heard ILOVETHATFORYOU. And had to read the blog in order to figure out what was "shady" about it---"shady", in these parts, implying something that is morally or legally dubious.
So the F and R of that answer were my final fills of what was a very enjoyable puzzle.

Loved this one; northwest and southeast were so daunting at first and stayed mostly blank for ages. In fact, at one point my solved  squares were perfectly symmetrical! 
I wish the original 13-Down clue had stayed.:)

A little on the easy side for a Friday but fun nonetheless. I always appreciate the skill of the constructor. 

I got to STONEHENGE in a roundabout way: I am not familiar with the band but was reminded of one of the penultimate scenes in the move ‚ÄúThis is Spinal Tap‚Äù where they have a Stonehenge set built for their show based on a design of a small scale replica ‚Äî except what gets built in the end is still the same size as what they thought was a small scale replica.  Anyway, thanks to the crosses I deduced STONEHENGE.  

Like at least one other commenter, I thought the clue for the answer ABLED was insensitive. Not sure how else you could clue that answer but the one the editor went with left me cold.

Apparently, I'm hip enough to know the saying, ILOVETHATFOR YOU (thanks to Schitt's Creek) but not hip enough to know that some people interpret it to be sarcastic. I just gave it a Goog and see that the fine people of the internet are somewhat split on whether it's casting shade or not. I'll just be sure to include a nose "Boop!" whenever I say it and hope for the best! I love that journey for me! As for HECTOR, that is surely a first for me. I do not think I've ever heard or read it but then again I've heard and read many things, so it is possible it just didn't stick. That R was my last fill. I wasn't sure about the baseball positions but a right-fielder made sense and it seemed the best ending for HECTO. Good to learn new things! Also, HECTOR brought this to mind, which I never mind thinking of ATALL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fVq4_HhBK8Y Oh, 63D - ANN - I knew this right away because she wrote one of my least favorite books and it made me wary of her name when looking at book options. Tons of people love it though, so who am I to say? In general, I thought this was a delightful puzzle! One grin after another at the misdirects and clever cluing! Top notch... with only one nit to pick: 53D's clue for ABLED. Others in the comments have addressed it better than I would but it is problematic and should be reconsidered for future puzzles. Other than that, truly a delight! STONEHENGE, MEGA, HENS, ILOVETHATFORYOU, ETCHASKETCH -- all lovely clues/entries.
I think I've scrolled all the way thru and, really, nobody's brought up Spinal Tap yet?  "Stone-enge" and something about demons been in my ear all day.
Where can I find the monthly extra puzzles on the app? TIA

Several years ago, I was a passenger in a freight truck driving down the NJ Turnpike when we came upon a tour bus with FATS Domino written on the side. I asked the driver to slow down.  As I was along side the driver, I rolled down my window and lipped to him, "Where's Fats?"  He pointed his thumb at his chest. Fats was driving his own tour bus. I did some searching when I got home, and he was appearing in Atlantic City in the coming days.
Loved this one all the way through.
ETCHASKETCH as a "drawer with knobs" mage my heart sing.

I didn't get HECTOR right away but after a few cross letters the word came back to me. I think I too would've delighted in the constructor's original T-Rex clue. For a time I was rehearsing with a T-Rex cover band, they were huge Mark Bolan stans/fans, I liked T-Rex but only knew the more famous songs. I have cassette tapes somewhere of our rehearsals... IIRC it was just for one special gig that we did, don't remember the details. Nice guys though, and good musicians; all had day-jobs. They had some clever T-Rex-related name for the band but I don't recall what. The rehearsals were good and fun. I might have to dig up those cassette tapes now! @Erma Yes, there is such a thing as an Oxford shoe (not that I'd ever heard of it), but Oxford is a university, Eton is a school. Perhaps one of those 'divided by a common language' things!

@Times Rita LOL! I hope you have forgiven her.

When I looked them up, I did know the style but didn't know what they were called. That's another thing to add to my ever-growing list of things I've learned from doing the NYT puzzle and reading the comments.

@Times Rita 

You probably know the difference, but the Amazon link (like most people these days) has many Derby-style shoes listed as oxfords, which is an admittedly odd pet peeve of mine. Ok, hard to do without pictures, but...

Oxfords have closed lacing, in which the vamp (front of shoe) comes all the way up to the ankle and is split for the lacing, with the tongue sewn under it. The laces close the side quarters, which leads to a clean, narrow-looking instep.  

Derbys have open lacing, in which the side quarters are sewn on top of the vamp, and the vamp goes under the laces (and the side quarters) leading to a wide looking instep. 

To me, two completely different looks (and fits - oxfords are tougher to fit), both instantly recognizable.  But, it looks like we're just going to call them both oxfords.  Sometimes I think language evolution's natural end is a single word for everything - context is key.

@Times Rita Ah yes, the teen trauma of parents who made you wear sensible shoes. And to add insult to injury, when our daughter was a teen, clunky was in. She actually wore silver sneakers to a school dance. And Doc Martens!
 Though 9 year-old granddaughter is showing an unhealthy interest in high heels these days. I threatened to disown her but of course she didn't believe me.

According to Chat GPT:

The verb ‚Äúhector,‚Äù meaning to bully or harass, has been utilized by several notable authors in their works. For instance:
	‚Ä¢	Jonathan Swift employed the term in his satirical writings.
	‚Ä¢	Henry Fielding used ‚Äúhector‚Äù in his novel The History of Tom Jones, a Foundling.
	‚Ä¢	Laurence Sterne included the word in The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman.

These examples illustrate the term‚Äôs presence in English literature, particularly during the 18th century.

The verb ‚Äúhector‚Äù originated in the mid-17th century, deriving from the name Hector, a Trojan prince in Greek mythology. The term came to describe blustering or bullying behavior, possibly influenced by a gang of youths in London known as ‚ÄúHectors‚Äù who were notorious for such conduct. Ôøº

In literature, ‚Äúhector‚Äù has been used to depict characters exhibiting domineering or bullying behavior. Its usage by authors like Swift, Fielding, and Sterne reflects its integration into the English lexicon during their time, enhancing character development and thematic expression in their narratives.

@Mean Old Lady 

Shakespeare used CURST a lot, though the big problem for the clue is that he used it as an adjective meaning "bad-tempered" or "angry", including an early description of the phenomenon of being "hangry", in The Winter's Tale III:iii:

"Ile go see if the Beare bee gone from the Gentleman, and how much he hath eaten: they are neuer curst but when they are hungry"

He occasionally used "curs'd" as a verb, but not with any connotation of "putting a hex on". For instance in The Tempest V:i Ferdinand says: "Though the Seas threaten they are mercifull,
I haue curs'd them without cause."

I think it may be a case of mistaken cluing.
